newsitem.title: USA: U.S. adj retail sales up 0.8 pct in Oct -- Redbook.
newsitem.headline: U.S. adj retail sales up 0.8 pct in Oct -- Redbook.

text.p: U.S. seasonally adjusted retail sales rose 0.8 percent in the first two weeks of fiscal October versus September, according to the Lynch, Jones & Ryan Inc Redbook retail sales index.

The index rose 7.6 percent when compared with the same month a year ago, the report said. Adjusted retail sales rose 7.5 percent in the week ended October 19, compared with the same week a year ago, it said.
Companies using the National Retail Federation calendar benefited by comparing the Columbus Day week with a non-holiday week last year, said Howard Eilenberg, a retail analyst of Redbook Research.
"The comparisons are relatively easy against a very weak October a year ago," said Eilenberg in an interview with Reuters Financial Television.
Eilenberg noted that discounters made a little bit of a comeback from last week, adding that one of the major retailers reported an upturn in soft goods and apparel.
"Soft goods and apparel now seem to be leading the other merchandise categories," said Eilenberg, adding that's been the case in the department stores and chain stores.
"For the first time, we are beginning to see apparels move in the discount stores," he added.
Eilenberg also said the rest of October should show positive results in retail sales.
